senses.definition: the act of joining two or more things together; the state of being joined together

examples.x: a meeting to discuss economic and currency union
Northern Ireland’s union with Britain
political union between the country and its neighbour
sexual union

senses.definition: a marriage

examples.x: Their union was blessed with six children.

senses.definition: a specific situation in which a product or service could be used

examples.x: There are many potential use cases for drones, from surveillance to leisure.

senses.definition: the process or activities by which a company adds value to a product, including production, marketing, etc.

examples.x: Every business needs to look very carefully at ways to optimize their value chain.

senses.definition: a business project or activity, especially one that involves taking risks adventure

examples.x: A disastrous business venture lost him thousands of dollars.

senses.definition: money that is invested in a new company to help it develop, which may involve a lot of risk
the person below the president of a country in rank, who takes control of the country if the president is not able to
a person in charge of a particular part of a business company

examples.x: the vice president of sales
He was appointed as vice president of business development the following year.

senses.definition: a way of advertising in which information about a company’s products or services is sent by email or social media to people who then send it on by email to other people they know

a small advertisement in a newspaper or on a website, placed in a section according to its subject, that is placed by a person or small company who wants to buy or sell something, find or offer a job, etc.
a building where large quantities of goods are stored, especially before they are sent to shops to be sold

examples.x: Police are investigating a fire at a furniture warehouse.

senses.definition: a person who does a lot of complicated deals in business or politics, often in a dishonest way
in large quantities, especially so they can be sold again to make a profit

examples.x: We buy the building materials wholesale.

senses.definition: in very large numbers

examples.x: These young people die wholesale from heroin overdoses.

senses.definition: the activity or business of producing wine
all the people who work for a particular company, organization, etc. lose

examples.x: The factory has a 1 000-strong workforce.
Two thirds of the workforce is/are women.

senses.definition: all the people in a country or an area who are available for work

examples.x: A quarter of the local workforce is/are unemployed.
an educated workforce

senses.definition: the money that is needed to run a business rather than the money that is used to buy buildings and equipment when starting the business
a period of discussion and practical work on a particular subject, in which a group of people share their knowledge and experience acquire/​get/​lack

examples.x: There will be the opportunity for practical theatre work in drama workshops.
She was invited to participate in a poetry workshop on campus.

senses.definition: a room or building in which things are made or repaired using tools or machines factory

examples.x: The craftsmen worked in a freezing cold workshop.
a car repair workshop

senses.definition: the total amount of crops, profits, etc. that are produced

examples.x: a high crop yield
a reduction in milk yield
This will give a yield of 10% on your investment.

senses.definition: to produce or provide something, for example a profit, result or crop

examples.x: Higher-rate deposit accounts yield good returns.
The research has yielded useful information.
These trees no longer yield fruit.
The project is expected to yield good returns in future.

senses.definition: to stop resisting something/somebody; to agree to do something that you do not want to do

examples.x: After a long siege, the town was forced to yield.
He reluctantly yielded to their demands.
I yielded to temptation and had a chocolate bar.

senses.definition: to allow somebody to win, have or take control of something that has been yours until now

examples.x: He refused to yield up his gun.
The universe is slowly yielding up its secrets.
archaeological remains which are yielding up secrets from long ago

senses.definition: to move, bend or break because of pressure

examples.x: Despite our attempts to break it, the lock would not yield.

senses.definition: to allow vehicles on a bigger road to go first

examples.x: Yield to oncoming traffic.
a yield sign
